rev.comment: This media use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.
rev.diff:
Line 108: Line 108:
1971 proved to be a professional turning point in Eastwood's career.<ref name="McGilligan196">McGilligan (1999), p.196</ref> Before Irving Leonard had died, the last film they had discussed at Malpaso was to give Eastwood the artistic control that he desired and make his directorial debut in ''[[Play Misty for Me]]''.<ref name="McGilligan192">McGilligan (1999), p.192</ref> The script was originally thought of by [[Jo Heims]], about a jazz disc jockey named Dave (Eastwood) who has a casual affair with Evelyn ([[Jessica Walter]]), one of his listeners who had been calling the radio station repeatedly at night asking him to play her favourite song, [[Erroll Garner]]'s ''[[Misty (song)|Misty]]''. When Dave ends their relationship the female fan becomes possessive and then violent, turning into a crazed murderess.<ref name="McGilligan193">McGilligan (1999), p.193</ref> Filming commenced in [[Monterey]] in September 1970, with Eastwood obtaining the rights to ''Misty'' after meeting Garner at the [[Concord Music Festival]] in 1970 and paying $2,000 for the use of the song ''[[The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face]]'' by [[Roberta Flack]].<ref name="McGilligan194">McGilligan (1999), p.194</ref> The film was highly acclaimed by critics, with critics such as [[Jay Cock]]s in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', [[Andrew Sarris]] in the ''[[Village Voice]]'' and [[Archer Winsten]] in the ''[[New York Post]]'' all praising Eastwood's directorial skills and the film, including his performance in the scenes with Walter.<ref name="McGilligan195">McGilligan (1999), p.195</ref>
1971 proved to be a professional turning point in Eastwood's career.<ref name="McGilligan196">McGilligan (1999), p.196</ref> Before Irving Leonard had died, the last film they had discussed at Malpaso was to give Eastwood the artistic control that he desired and make his directorial debut in ''[[Play Misty for Me]]''.<ref name="McGilligan192">McGilligan (1999), p.192</ref> The script was originally thought of by [[Jo Heims]], about a jazz disc jockey named Dave (Eastwood) who has a casual affair with Evelyn ([[Jessica Walter]]), one of his listeners who had been calling the radio station repeatedly at night asking him to play her favourite song, [[Erroll Garner]]'s ''[[Misty (song)|Misty]]''. When Dave ends their relationship the female fan becomes possessive and then violent, turning into a crazed murderess.<ref name="McGilligan193">McGilligan (1999), p.193</ref> Filming commenced in [[Monterey]] in September 1970, with Eastwood obtaining the rights to ''Misty'' after meeting Garner at the [[Concord Music Festival]] in 1970 and paying $2,000 for the use of the song ''[[The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face]]'' by [[Roberta Flack]].<ref name="McGilligan194">McGilligan (1999), p.194</ref> The film was highly acclaimed by critics, with critics such as [[Jay Cock]]s in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', [[Andrew Sarris]] in the ''[[Village Voice]]'' and [[Archer Winsten]] in the ''[[New York Post]]'' all praising Eastwood's directorial skills and the film, including his performance in the scenes with Walter.<ref name="McGilligan195">McGilligan (1999), p.195</ref>
â   â
[[File:Harry Callahan.JPG|thumb|left|Eastwood as Inspector "Dirty" Harry Callahan in ''[[Dirty Harry]]'']]
 
The script to ''[[Dirty Harry]]'' was originally written by [[Harry Julian]] and [[Rita M. Fink]], a story about a hard-edged [[New York City]] (later changed to [[San Francisco]]) police inspector [[Harry Callahan (character)|Harry Callahan]], determined to stop a psychotic killer by any means at his disposal.<ref name="McGilligan205">McGilligan (1999), p.205</ref> Dirty Harry is arguably Eastwood's most memorable character and the lines that Callahan utters when addressing a wounded bank robber are often cited amongst the most memorable in cinematic history (see box). The film has been credited with inventing the "loose-cannon cop genre" that is imitated to this day. Eastwood's tough, no-nonsense portrayal of Dirty Harry touched a cultural nerve with many who were fed up with crime in the streets and at a time when there were prevalent reports of local and federal police committing atrocities and overstepping their authority by entrapment and obstruction of justice.<ref name="McGilligan209">McGilligan (1999), p.209</ref> ''Dirty Harry'' marked the beginning of Eastwood's work with legendary [[film poster]] designer [[Bill Gold]]. Gold designed (and often photographed) posters for 35 Clint Eastwood films, from ''Dirty Harry'' to ''[[Million Dollar Baby]]'' (2004). After release in December 1971, Dirty Harry proved a phenonemal success which would be go on to become Siegel's highest grossing film and the start of a series of films which is arguably Eastwood's signature role, with fans demanding more. Although a number of critics such as Jay Cocks of ''Time'' praised his performance as Dirty Harry, describing him as "giving his best performance so far, tense, tough, full of implicit identification with his character",<ref name="McGilligan210">McGilligan (1999), p.210</ref> the film was widely criticized and accused of [[fascism]] through Eastwood's portrayal of the ruthless cop. [[Feminism|Feminists]] in particular were outraged by the film and at the Oscars for 1971 protested outside holding up banners which read messages such as "Dirty Harry is a Rotten Pig".<ref>Schickel (1996), p.281</ref>
The script to ''[[Dirty Harry]]'' was originally written by [[Harry Julian]] and [[Rita M. Fink]], a story about a hard-edged [[New York City]] (later changed to [[San Francisco]]) police inspector [[Harry Callahan (character)|Harry Callahan]], determined to stop a psychotic killer by any means at his disposal.<ref name="McGilligan205">McGilligan (1999), p.205</ref> Dirty Harry is arguably Eastwood's most memorable character and the lines that Callahan utters when addressing a wounded bank robber are often cited amongst the most memorable in cinematic history (see box). The film has been credited with inventing the "loose-cannon cop genre" that is imitated to this day. Eastwood's tough, no-nonsense portrayal of Dirty Harry touched a cultural nerve with many who were fed up with crime in the streets and at a time when there were prevalent reports of local and federal police committing atrocities and overstepping their authority by entrapment and obstruction of justice.<ref name="McGilligan209">McGilligan (1999), p.209</ref> ''Dirty Harry'' marked the beginning of Eastwood's work with legendary [[film poster]] designer [[Bill Gold]]. Gold designed (and often photographed) posters for 35 Clint Eastwood films, from ''Dirty Harry'' to ''[[Million Dollar Baby]]'' (2004). After release in December 1971, Dirty Harry proved a phenonemal success which would be go on to become Siegel's highest grossing film and the start of a series of films which is arguably Eastwood's signature role, with fans demanding more. Although a number of critics such as Jay Cocks of ''Time'' praised his performance as Dirty Harry, describing him as "giving his best performance so far, tense, tough, full of implicit identification with his character",<ref name="McGilligan210">McGilligan (1999), p.210</ref> the film was widely criticized and accused of [[fascism]] through Eastwood's portrayal of the ruthless cop. [[Feminism|Feminists]] in particular were outraged by the film and at the Oscars for 1971 protested outside holding up banners which read messages such as "Dirty Harry is a Rotten Pig".<ref>Schickel (1996), p.281</ref>
Line 163: Line 161:
In 1982, Eastwood directed and starred in ''[[Honkytonk Man]]'', based on the novel by [[Clancy Carlile]] about an aspiring country music singer named Red Stovall, set during the [[Great Depression]]. The script was adapted slightly from the novel; the scene in the novel of where Red gives a reefer to his fourteen-year old son (played by real-life son Kyle) was not approved by Eastwood and altered and the ending was also changed to the playing on the radio of a song written by Red on his death bed, shortly before his burial.<ref>McGilligan (1999), p.344</ref> The film was shot in the summer of 1982 within six weeks.<ref>McGilligan (1999), p.345</ref> The first part of the movie was filmed in [[Bird's Landing, California]], although the majority of this feature was filmed in and around [[Calaveras County, California|Calaveras County]], east of [[Stockton, California]]. Exterior scenes include Main Street, [[Mountain Ranch, California|Mountain Ranch]]; Main Street, [[Sheepranch, California|Sheepranch]]; and the Pioneer Hotel in Sheepranch. Extras were locally hired and many of the towns residents are seen in the movie. The film received a mixed reception upon release, although its has a high score of 93% on [[Rotten Tomatoes]]. In 1982, Eastwood also directed, produced and starred in the [[Cold War]]-themed ''[[Firefox (film)|Firefox]]'', based on a 1977 [[Firefox (novel)|novel with the same name]] by British novelist [[Craig Thomas (author)|Craig Thomas]]. ''Firefox'' is an espionage thriller, about a retired Air Force Special Forces Expert, recruited to steal a Soviet supersonic war plane from [[Moscow]]. Russian filming locations were not possible due to the [[Cold War]], and much footage was shot at the [[Thule Air Base]] in [[Greenland]] and in [[Austria]] to simulate many of the Eurasian story locations.<ref>McGilligan (1999), p.337</ref> The film was actually shot before ''Honkeytonk Man'' but was released after it.
In 1982, Eastwood directed and starred in ''[[Honkytonk Man]]'', based on the novel by [[Clancy Carlile]] about an aspiring country music singer named Red Stovall, set during the [[Great Depression]]. The script was adapted slightly from the novel; the scene in the novel of where Red gives a reefer to his fourteen-year old son (played by real-life son Kyle) was not approved by Eastwood and altered and the ending was also changed to the playing on the radio of a song written by Red on his death bed, shortly before his burial.<ref>McGilligan (1999), p.344</ref> The film was shot in the summer of 1982 within six weeks.<ref>McGilligan (1999), p.345</ref> The first part of the movie was filmed in [[Bird's Landing, California]], although the majority of this feature was filmed in and around [[Calaveras County, California|Calaveras County]], east of [[Stockton, California]]. Exterior scenes include Main Street, [[Mountain Ranch, California|Mountain Ranch]]; Main Street, [[Sheepranch, California|Sheepranch]]; and the Pioneer Hotel in Sheepranch. Extras were locally hired and many of the towns residents are seen in the movie. The film received a mixed reception upon release, although its has a high score of 93% on [[Rotten Tomatoes]]. In 1982, Eastwood also directed, produced and starred in the [[Cold War]]-themed ''[[Firefox (film)|Firefox]]'', based on a 1977 [[Firefox (novel)|novel with the same name]] by British novelist [[Craig Thomas (author)|Craig Thomas]]. ''Firefox'' is an espionage thriller, about a retired Air Force Special Forces Expert, recruited to steal a Soviet supersonic war plane from [[Moscow]]. Russian filming locations were not possible due to the [[Cold War]], and much footage was shot at the [[Thule Air Base]] in [[Greenland]] and in [[Austria]] to simulate many of the Eurasian story locations.<ref>McGilligan (1999), p.337</ref> The film was actually shot before ''Honkeytonk Man'' but was released after it.
â   â
[[File:Sudden-impact-10.jpg|left|thumbnail|215px|"[[Go ahead, make my day]]"]]
 
The fourth ''Dirty Harry'' film ''[[Sudden Impact]]'' (1983), is widely considered to be the darkest, "dirtiest" and most violent film of the series. This would be the last time he starred in a film with frequent leading lady [[Sondra Locke]]. The script, written by [[Joseph Stinson]], is about a woman (Locke) who avenges the [[rape]] of herself and her sister (now a vegetable) by a ruthless gang at a fairground. The woman systematically murders her rapists one by one, shooting them once in the genitals and once in the head. Pat Hingle and [[Bradford Dillman]] also starred alongside Eastwood and footage was shot in the spring and early summer of 1983. The line, "[[Go ahead, make my day]]", uttered by Eastwood during an earlier scene in which his regular morning cafe is threatened by robbers, is often cited as one of cinema's immortal lines and was famously referenced by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Ronald Reagan]] in his campaigns. The film was the highest earning of all the Dirty Harry films, earning $70 million and received rave reviews, with many critics praising the feminist aspects of the film through its explorations of the physical and psychological consequences of rape.<ref>McGilligan (1999), p.352</ref>
The fourth ''Dirty Harry'' film ''[[Sudden Impact]]'' (1983), is widely considered to be the darkest, "dirtiest" and most violent film of the series. This would be the last time he starred in a film with frequent leading lady [[Sondra Locke]]. The script, written by [[Joseph Stinson]], is about a woman (Locke) who avenges the [[rape]] of herself and her sister (now a vegetable) by a ruthless gang at a fairground. The woman systematically murders her rapists one by one, shooting them once in the genitals and once in the head. Pat Hingle and [[Bradford Dillman]] also starred alongside Eastwood and footage was shot in the spring and early summer of 1983. The line, "[[Go ahead, make my day]]", uttered by Eastwood during an earlier scene in which his regular morning cafe is threatened by robbers, is often cited as one of cinema's immortal lines and was famously referenced by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Ronald Reagan]] in his campaigns. The film was the highest earning of all the Dirty Harry films, earning $70 million and received rave reviews, with many critics praising the feminist aspects of the film through its explorations of the physical and psychological consequences of rape.<ref>McGilligan (1999), p.352</ref>
Line 261: Line 257:
====Sondra Locke====
====Sondra Locke====
â
[[File:Eastwood Locke.jpg|right|thumb|Eastwood and Sondra Locke in their 1977 film ''[[The Gauntlet (film)|The Gauntlet]]'']]
  â  
Eastwood had a fourteen-year relationship with actress [[Sondra Locke]], whom he met in 1972,<ref name="Eliot147">Eliot (2009) p.147</ref> and co-starred in six films: ''[[The Outlaw Josey Wales]]'', ''[[The Gauntlet (film)|The Gauntlet]]'', ''[[Every Which Way but Loose (film)|Every Which Way but Loose]]'', ''[[Bronco Billy]]'', ''[[Any Which Way You Can]]'', and ''[[Sudden Impact]]''. Locke had been married in name only to sculptor Gordon Anderson since 1967, and they had separated shortly after Anderson [[came out]] as a homosexual.<ref name="McGilligan" /> Eastwood, who remained married to Maggie Johnson during the first half of the relationship, was aware of this and even purchased a house for Anderson and his partner to live in.<ref name="McGilligan" /> Locke became pregnant by Eastwood twice, had two [[abortions]] (she later wrote it was "a mutual decision") and then a [[tubal ligation]] (at Eastwood's request).<ref name="Eliot193">Eliot (2009), p.193</ref><ref name="AborTub">{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Sondra Locke Suing Clint Eastwood|work=[[Sun Journal (Lewiston)|Lewiston Journal]]|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=H70gAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sWkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4573%2C3414437|date=April 28, 1989|accessdate=April 29, 2010}}</ref> The couple split acrimoniously in 1989. While Locke was away directing the film ''[[Impulse]]'', Eastwood had the locks changed on the home they shared and placed all of her belongings into a storage facility.<ref name="McGilligan" /> She filed a [[palimony]] suit against Eastwood, and the litigation continued for a decade, with Locke suing him a second time for [[fraud]].<ref name="FraudSue">{{cite news|last=O'Neill|first=Ann W.|title=Sondra Locke Suing Clint Eastwood|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/16576835.html?dids=16576835:16576835&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Sep+18%2C+1996&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&desc=Eastwood+Denies+Fraud+in+Film+Deal+for+Former+Lover&pqatl=google|format=Fee required|date=September 18, 1996|accessdate=April 29, 2010}}</ref> Locke and Eastwood finally resolved the dispute with a non-public settlement in 1999.<ref name="McGilligan" /><ref name="Settle">{{cite news|last=Huffaker|first=Donna|title=Eastwood's Ex Settles With Warner Bros.|work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]]|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-83612488.html|format=Fee required|publisher=[[Highbeam Research]]|date=May 25, 1999|accessdate=April 29, 2010}}</ref> She published a memoir, ''The Good, the Bad, and the Very Ugly'', which includes a harrowing account of their years together.
Eastwood had a fourteen-year relationship with actress [[Sondra Locke]], whom he met in 1972,<ref name="Eliot147">Eliot (2009) p.147</ref> and co-starred in six films: ''[[The Outlaw Josey Wales]]'', ''[[The Gauntlet (film)|The Gauntlet]]'', ''[[Every Which Way but Loose (film)|Every Which Way but Loose]]'', ''[[Bronco Billy]]'', ''[[Any Which Way You Can]]'', and ''[[Sudden Impact]]''. Locke had been married in name only to sculptor Gordon Anderson since 1967, and they had separated shortly after Anderson [[came out]] as a homosexual.<ref name="McGilligan" /> Eastwood, who remained married to Maggie Johnson during the first half of the relationship, was aware of this and even purchased a house for Anderson and his partner to live in.<ref name="McGilligan" /> Locke became pregnant by Eastwood twice, had two [[abortions]] (she later wrote it was "a mutual decision") and then a [[tubal ligation]] (at Eastwood's request).<ref name="Eliot193">Eliot (2009), p.193</ref><ref name="AborTub">{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Sondra Locke Suing Clint Eastwood|work=[[Sun Journal (Lewiston)|Lewiston Journal]]|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=H70gAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sWkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4573%2C3414437|date=April 28, 1989|accessdate=April 29, 2010}}</ref> The couple split acrimoniously in 1989. While Locke was away directing the film ''[[Impulse]]'', Eastwood had the locks changed on the home they shared and placed all of her belongings into a storage facility.<ref name="McGilligan" /> She filed a [[palimony]] suit against Eastwood, and the litigation continued for a decade, with Locke suing him a second time for [[fraud]].<ref name="FraudSue">{{cite news|last=O'Neill|first=Ann W.|title=Sondra Locke Suing Clint Eastwood|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/16576835.html?dids=16576835:16576835&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Sep+18%2C+1996&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&desc=Eastwood+Denies+Fraud+in+Film+Deal+for+Former+Lover&pqatl=google|format=Fee required|date=September 18, 1996|accessdate=April 29, 2010}}</ref> Locke and Eastwood finally resolved the dispute with a non-public settlement in 1999.<ref name="McGilligan" /><ref name="Settle">{{cite news|last=Huffaker|first=Donna|title=Eastwood's Ex Settles With Warner Bros.|work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]]|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-83612488.html|format=Fee required|publisher=[[Highbeam Research]]|date=May 25, 1999|accessdate=April 29, 2010}}</ref> She published a memoir, ''The Good, the Bad, and the Very Ugly'', which includes a harrowing account of their years together.
